name: Belgrade
fun_fact: Fun fact: In Serbia, rakija (fruit brandy) is treated as medicine! When children have fevers, parents rub rakija on their chest to 'pull out high temperatures.' Sore throat? Wrap a cloth soaked in rakija around your neck. The traditional morning ritual in Serbian villages goes: first eat 1-2 teaspoons of slatko (caramelized fruit sugar), then drink coffee, then rakija. As locals humorously explain: 'Germs gather around slatko, coffee blacks them out, then rakija kills them all!' People even buried homemade rakija underground and dug it up for births or marriages. Every Serbian house has rakijaâ€”'without that, it's not home. It's cultural.'

hero_dishes.name: Sarma
hero_dishes.description: Cabbage rolls stuffed with a mixture of minced meat, rice, and spices. Tangy, savory, and tenderâ€”warming body and soul.
hero_dishes.origin_story: The most popular winter meal and highly regarded dish in Serbian cuisine. Traditionally served in colder months, during Christmas, and at family gatherings. Sarma represents home cooking and grandmother's kitchenâ€”it takes hours to prepare and is made with love.

hero_dishes.name: Pljeskavica
hero_dishes.description: A large, flavorful ground meat patty similar to a burger, often accompanied by kajmak and onions. Much bigger and more seasoned than a typical hamburger.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Balkan grilling classic, pljeskavica showcases the Serbian love for charcoal-grilled meats and rich dairy. The patty is typically made from a mix of meats (beef, pork, lamb) and can be stuffed with cheese.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Cirino Drvce for juicy, smoky pljeskavica made with free-range bull meat. Traditional kafanas and grills throughout the city.

hero_dishes.name: Ajvar
hero_dishes.description: A delicious relish made from red peppers, eggplant, garlic, and chili. Used as a condiment for grilled meats and bread.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A staple in every Serbian household, ajvar is made in late summer when peppers are abundant. Families spend days roasting and preparing large batches to preserve for winterâ€”it's a communal, cultural event.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Served as a condiment at every Serbian restaurant, available at markets and in jars at shops

signature_drinks.name: Rakija (Fruit Brandy)
signature_drinks.description: Clear brandy made from distilled, fermented fruit. Alcohol content normally 40% ABV, but homemade can be 50-80%. Types include Å¡ljivovica (plumsâ€”the most iconic), kajsija (apricots), dunja (quince), lozovaÄa (grapes).
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Rakija is the soul of Serbiaâ€”'every house has some kind of rakija. Without that, it's not home. It's cultural.' In villages, people drink rakija with coffee when they wake up. The morning ritual: eat slatko (caramelized fruit), drink coffee, then rakija to 'kill all the germs.' Used medicinallyâ€”rubbed on children's chests for fevers, wrapped around necks for sore throats. People buried homemade rakija and dug it up for births or marriages. Belgrade's rakija scene includes Ambar (40+ varieties), Rakia Bar Belgrade (54 rakijas on a menu printed like a CD case), even Manastir Kovilj made by monks!

signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Drinking coffee in Serbia does NOT mean drinking it quicklyâ€”it's a ritual that begins with the very act of preparing it. Coffee is drunk on every occasion, and it's basic courtesy to offer coffee to visitors. After finishing, there's a tradition of 'gledanje u Å¡olju' (fortune telling): flip your cup upside down on a saucer, and when you pick it up, the coffee residue patterns supposedly foretell the future. Coffee culture is central to Serbian social life.

food_culture_notes: Belgrade has transformed into the capital of 'new Balkan cuisine'â€”earning its first Michelin star and embracing slow food culture
The 'new Balkan cuisine' movement (led by chefs like Vanja) revives traditional ingredients and centuries-old kafana recipes
Serbian food reflects influences from Ottoman Empire to Austro-Hungarian traditions
Traditional dishes are hearty, flavorful, and 'almost always made with love'
Serbs are proud of their gastronomy and want people to understand 'where we come from and where we want to go'
The Slava (family feast for patron saint) is a distinctive Serbian traditionâ€”recognized by UNESCO as Intangible Cultural Heritage
Bread is considered sacredâ€”it's customary to break rather than cut it
Traditional folk music and kolo dance (circle dance) symbolize unity and joy at celebrations
Kafanas are cultural institutions, not just restaurantsâ€”they're where history, music, rakija, and food intersect
Grilled meats are central to Serbian cuisineâ€”charcoal grilling is an art form
Kajmak (clotted cream) appears in countless dishesâ€”a distinctly Balkan dairy product
Hospitality is intenseâ€”locals take pride in welcoming guests with abundant food and drink
